Celebrate our centennial anniversary!
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

On Sunday, January 12, join us for an exhibition and community party to celebrate the ACLU's 100th birthday.

We will celebrate and honor the ACLU's role in St. Louis's fight for justice since 1920:

  • The struggle to end police brutality in the 1930s, 1960s, and 1980s.
  • Before the workhouse was open, there was another municipal prison. Activists worked to close it.
  • The historic struggle for LGBTQ+ rights in St. Louis.
  • The founder of the National ACLU, Roger Baldwin, lived in St. Louis in the 1910s. He returned often to Missouri to canoe the Meramec and visit friends, some of whom will be at our celebration.
  • And more.

Celebrate 100 Years of ACLU MO

Sunday, January 12, 2:30 – 4:30 p.m.
John M. Olin Library
St. Louis, MO 63130

Please note: This link will take you to a third-party website, facebook.com
RSVP TODAY

We'll have button-making and story-reading for kids, plus snacks and drinks.

We are thrilled to give a special award to Joyce Armstrong, our first Executive Director, who served for 25 years. We go on today because of Joyce and other activists.

No tickets are necessary. All are welcome. Please RSVP to Josh Cornier at jcornier@aclu-mo.org, or on the Facebook event page.

For parking details and other information, check out our website!

We look forward to seeing you there,

ACLU of Missouri

P.S. Join us on Tuesday, February 12 for our 5th annual Voices of Liberty Lobby Day!
